brief_description of the content in the: The page describes a rule for using @Around advice in Aspect Oriented Programming (AOP). It states that the method annotated with @Around must call org.aspectj.lang.ProceedingJoinPoint#proceed and return its result. The method must have ProceedingJoinPoint as the first argument and Object as the return type. If these conditions are not met, it is likely a coding error.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'around_advice_style_inspection' checks all classes and their methods. If a method is annotated with '@Around', it asserts that the first argument of the method is 'ProceedingJoinPoint' and the return type is 'Object'. If these conditions are not met, it generates a message indicating the method and class that do not follow the @Around advice style.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-aop-advice-tutorial
Summary: This tutorial on Baeldung explains the different types of advice in Spring AOP, including @Around. It emphasizes the importance of calling proceed() and returning its result in an @Around advice.

2. URL: https://www.javatpoint.com/around-advice-in-spring-aop
Summary: JavaTPoint provides a detailed guide on using @Around advice in Spring AOP. It also mentions the necessity of having ProceedingJoinPoint as an argument and returning the result of proceed().
